title: The Ghana Radio Astronomy Observatory
summary: The Ghana Radio Astronomy Observatory (GRAO) marks a pivotal advance in African radio astronomy through the successful transformation of a decommissioned 32 m satellite communication antenna into a scientifically capable, VLBI-ready radio telescope. Strategically located near the equator at Kutunse, Ghana, the telescope offers nearly full-sky coverage (-77 degrees to +88 degrees declination), making it a valuable asset for time-domain astronomy, transient surveys, and global VLBI networks. This work documents the technical evolution of the facility, including beam-waveguide optics, dual-polarization C-band receivers (5 and 6.7 GHz), and recent backend upgrades culminating in the integration of a hydrogen maser, wideband ROACH2 system, and enhanced control and pointing infrastructure. We report early science results from high-resolution spectral-line observations of 6.7 GHz Class II methanol masers, pulse timing of PSR J0835-4510 (Vela), and successful VLBI fringe detections on intercontinental baselines. Simulations and commissioning tests confirm high aperture efficiency (>77%), low sidelobe levels, and robust time stability across the signal chain. These outcomes validate the GRAO's readiness for both standalone and networked operations. As the first operational node in West Africa contributing to the African VLBI Network, GRAO plays a critical role in advancing the continent's participation in global radio astronomy, capacity building, and the preparatory phase of the Square Kilometre Array.

AI.tldr: The GRAO converted a decommissioned satellite antenna into a functional radio telescope in Ghana, offering extensive sky coverage and advanced capabilities for radio astronomy research, including VLBI. Early science results and technical upgrades validate its readiness for global collaborations and SKA preparation.
AI.motivation: To establish Ghana's presence in radio astronomy, leverage its strategic equatorial location, and contribute to international networks like the African VLBI Network and SKA. Also aims to enhance capacity building in Africa.
AI.method: Technical upgrades included beam-waveguide optics, dual-polarization C-band receivers, hydrogen maser clock, ROACH2 backend systems, and improved control infrastructure. Conducted spectral-line observations, pulsar timing, and VLBI fringe detection tests.
AI.result: Achieved high aperture efficiency (>77%), low sidelobes, stable timing. Successfully observed methanol masers, Vela pulsar, and obtained intercontinental VLBI fringes, confirming operational readiness.
AI.conclusion: GRAO is a validated asset for standalone and networked radio astronomy, advancing Africa's role in global projects like the SKA. It serves as a critical node for capacity building and future large-scale collaborations.

title: Diagnosing the Effects of Spectroscopic Training Set Imperfection on Photometric Redshift Performance
comment: 22 pages, 11 figures, for submission to MNRAS
summary: Most LSST extragalactic science will rely on photometric redshifts (photo-$z$) to extract distance information for the galaxies. However, an incomplete or non-representative training set can introduce bias into photo-$z$ estimation. It is necessary to understand how various forms of training set imperfection, such as incompleteness and non-trivial spectroscopic target selection, affect photo-$z$ estimation algorithms, and to identify metrics best-suited to quantify the impact. This work aims to systematically study metrics for diagnosing how various photo-$z$ methods react to certain types of training set incompleteness and non-representativeness. We use methods available through the open-source Python library Redshift Assessment Infrastructure Layers (RAIL) to systematically test the algorithms CMNN, GPz, FlexZBoost, and PZFlow on mock training data degraded in accordance with several existing spectroscopic sky surveys, as well as under conditions of inverse redshift incompleteness, which approximately mimics observed patterns of incompleteness at high redshift. We employ the algorithm TrainZ as a control. Finally, we quantify photo-$z$ algorithm performance using a variety of statistical metrics implemented externally to RAIL. We determine that the Kullback-Liebler Divergence, Wasserstein Distance, and Probability Integral Transform are particularly informative metrics with which to assess the impact of training set imperfection on algorithmic performance. We also find that inverse redshift incompleteness effects alone lack the complexity to realistically represent anticipated training data.

AI.tldr: The paper studies how training set imperfections affect photo-z algorithms and identifies effective metrics to assess their performance.
AI.motivation: To understand and quantify the impact of incomplete or biased training data on photometric redshift estimation accuracy.
AI.method: They tested CMNN, GPz, FlexZBoost, and PZFlow algorithms using RAIL on mock data mimicking real spectroscopic surveys and inverse redshift incompleteness. Metrics like KL divergence and Wasserstein Distance were used.
AI.result: Kullback-Leibler Divergence, Wasserstein Distance, and Probability Integral Transform are effective metrics. Inverse redshift incompleteness alone isn't complex enough to represent real training data issues.
AI.conclusion: Key metrics for diagnosing training data impacts were identified, highlighting the need for more complex incompleteness models in evaluations.

title: Optimal and Unbiased Fluxes from Up-the-Ramp Detectors under Variable Illumination
summary: Near-infrared (NIR) detectors -- which use non-destructive readouts to measure time-series counts-per-pixel -- play a crucial role in modern astrophysics. Standard NIR flux extraction techniques were developed for space-based observations and assume that source fluxes are constant over an observation. However, ground-based telescopes often see short-timescale atmospheric variations that can dramatically change the number of photons arriving at a pixel. This work presents a new statistical model that shares information between neighboring spectral pixels to characterize time-variable observations and extract unbiased fluxes with optimal uncertainties. We generate realistic synthetic data using a variety of flux and amplitude-of-time-variability conditions to confirm that our model recovers unbiased and optimal estimates of both the true flux and the time-variable signal. We find that the time-variable model should be favored over a constant-flux model when the observed count rates change by more than 3.5%. Ignoring time variability in the data can result in flux-dependent, unknown-sign biases that are as large as ~120% of the flux uncertainty. Using real APOGEE spectra, we find empirical evidence for approximately wavelength-independent, time-dependent variations in count rates with amplitudes much greater than the 3.5% threshold. Our model can robustly measure and remove the time-dependence in real data, improving the quality of data-model comparison. We show several examples where the observed time-dependence quantitatively agrees with independent measurements of observing conditions, such as variable cloud cover and seeing.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new statistical model for near-infrared detectors that accounts for short-term atmospheric variations in ground-based observations. This model reduces biases and improves flux estimation, demonstrating effectiveness through synthetic and real APOGEE data.
AI.motivation: Standard NIR flux extraction methods assume constant flux over observations, but ground-based telescopes face atmospheric variations causing significant photon count fluctuations. Existing approaches fail to handle these time-dependent variations, leading to potential biases in flux measurements.
AI.method: The model shares information between neighboring spectral pixels to characterize time-variable observations, using synthetic data with varied flux and time-variability conditions. It determines when the time-variable model outperforms constant-flux models based on count rate changes exceeding 3.5%.
AI.result: The model recovers unbiased flux and time-variable signals effectively. Real APOGEE spectra show time-dependent variations larger than 3.5%, and the model successfully removes time-dependence, aligning with independent measurements like cloud cover and seeing.
AI.conclusion: Ignoring time variability introduces flux biases up to 120% of uncertainties. The new model improves data quality and accuracy, critical for ground-based NIR astrophysics.

title: A Novel, Beam-based Formalism for Active Impedance of Phased Arrays
summary: The active impedance is a fundamental parameter for characterizing the behavior of large, uniform phased array antennas. However, its conventional calculation via the mutual impedance matrix (or the scattering matrix) offers limited physical intuition and can be computationally intensive. This paper presents a novel derivation of the active impedance directly from the radiated beam pattern of such arrays. This approach maps the scan-angle variation of the active impedance directly to the intrinsic angular variation of the beam, providing a more intuitive physical interpretation. The theoretical derivation is straightforward and rigorous. The validity of the proposed equation is conclusively confirmed through full-wave simulations of a prototype array. This work establishes a new and more intuitive framework for understanding, analyzing and accurately measuring the scan-dependent variations in phased arrays, which is one of the main challenges in modern phased array designs. Consequently, this novel formalism is expected to expedite and simplify the overall design and optimization process for next-generation, large-scale uniform phased arrays.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a new method to calculate active impedance in large phased arrays using radiated beam patterns, offering a more intuitive and computationally efficient approach compared to traditional methods involving mutual impedance matrices.
AI.motivation: The conventional method for calculating active impedance is computationally intensive and lacks physical intuition. The goal is to provide a clearer understanding and simpler way to analyze scan-dependent variations in phased arrays.
AI.method: The authors derive the active impedance directly from the radiated beam pattern, linking the scan-angle variation of impedance to the angular variation of the beam. This theoretical framework is validated through full-wave simulations of a prototype array.
AI.result: The proposed equation accurately predicts the active impedance variations, confirmed by simulations. This method provides a clear physical interpretation and simplifies analysis.
AI.conclusion: The new framework facilitates faster design and optimization of large-scale phased arrays by offering an intuitive approach to understanding and measuring scan-dependent behaviors.

title: Narrowing Down Sources of High-Frequency Gravitational Waves
summary: Detecting gravitational waves above 100 kHz would constitute a major discovery, as any observable signal would have to arise from new physics within the late universe. Although many technologies have been identified to explore this high-frequency regime, the known landscape of promising sources remains extremely sparse. In this work, we aim to rectify this issue by providing model-independent arguments that highlight the most interesting parts of theory space, while remaining agnostic of the specific signal mechanism. For example, energy-conservation implies that gravitational waves detectable by future experiments well above a MHz would most likely have to originate from within the Solar System. Based on these arguments, we also constrain the physical properties of such sources.

AI.tldr: The paper aims to identify promising high-frequency gravitational wave (GW) sources above 100 kHz by analyzing theoretical constraints, particularly emphasizing that signals above 1 MHz likely originate within the Solar System due to energy conservation limits.
AI.motivation: To address the sparse theoretical landscape of high-frequency GW sources (>100 kHz) and identify regions of parameter space where future experiments might detect signals without assuming specific emission mechanisms.
AI.method: Uses model-independent arguments based on energy conservation and physical constraints to delineate viable GW source parameters, focusing on frequency ranges and source locations (e.g., Solar System constraints for signals above 1 MHz).
AI.result: Establishes that detectable GWs above ~1 MHz must originate within the Solar System due to energy limits. Provides constraints on source properties like energy emission rates and lifetimes for potential candidates.
AI.conclusion: Future high-frequency GW experiments should prioritize searching within the Solar System for signals above 1 MHz. This work frameworks a systematic approach to explore uncharted GW sources without relying on specific models.

title: Astrometric microlensing probes of the isolated neutron star population with Roman
summary: Notoriously hard to detect and study, isolated neutron stars (NS) could provide valuable answers to fundamental questions about stellar evolution and explosion physics. With the upcoming Roman Space Telescope, scheduled for launch in 2026, a new and powerful channel for their detection - astrometric microlensing - will become available. We set out to create a realistic sample of simulated gravitational microlensing events as observed by Roman with the Galactic Bulge Time Domain Survey. We focus in particular on the population of NS lenses, which has until now been largely understudied. We use state-of-the-art Galactic models tailored for application to microlensing by compact objects. We simulate four different NS populations with Maxwellian natal kick distributions: $\bar{v} = (150, \ 250, \ 350, \ 450)$ km/s. We apply projected Roman precision, cadence, and detectability criteria. We find the parameter space $\log_{10} t_{\rm E}$ - $\log_{10} θ_{\rm E}$, which will be accessible to Roman observations, to be maximally efficient for classification of stellar remnants. We find a feature in this space that is characteristic to NS; using this feature, optimal samples of NS candidates can be constructed from Roman-like datasets. We describe the dependence of observable parameter distributions on the assumed mean kick velocities. As the effects of natal kicks are very complex and mutually counteracting, we suggest more detailed studies focused on the dynamics of NS are needed in anticipation of Roman and future surveys. We estimate Roman will observe approximately $11\,000$ microlensing events - including $\sim100$ with NS lenses - whose both photometric and astrometric signal are detectable; the event yield decreases by $38\%$ if gap-filling low-cadence observations are not included. We make all simulated microlensing event datasets publicly available in preparation for Roman data.

AI.tldr: The study demonstrates the potential of using the Roman Space Telescope's astrometric microlensing technique to detect isolated neutron stars. By simulating microlensing events with different natal kick velocities, the authors show that Roman could identify around 100 neutron star lenses among 11,000 events, highlighting a characteristic feature in the parameter space for their classification.
AI.motivation: Isolated neutron stars are poorly understood due to detection challenges, yet they hold answers about stellar evolution and explosions. The Roman Space Telescope's capabilities offer a new detection method (astrometric microlensing), necessitating simulations to evaluate its potential.
AI.method: The team simulated gravitational microlensing events using Galactic models tailored for compact objects, testing four neutron star populations with varying mean natal kick velocities (150-450 km/s). They applied Roman's expected observational parameters (precision, cadence) to analyze detectability and parameter space efficiency.
AI.result: Roman's parameter space (log t_E vs log θ_E) is optimal for classifying stellar remnants, with a distinct neutron star feature aiding candidate selection. Approximately 100 neutron star events with detectable signals are expected, dropping to ~62 without low-cadence gap-filling. All simulated data were released publicly.
AI.conclusion: Roman's astrometric microlensing can significantly advance neutron star studies, but complex natal kick dynamics require further research. The findings emphasize the telescope's role in uncovering rare neutron star events and the importance of detailed population modeling.

title: Shadow signatures and energy accumulation in Lorentzian-Euclidean black holes
summary: The Lorentzian-Euclidean black hole has been recently introduced as a geodesically complete spacetime featuring a signature shift at the event horizon where causal geodesics are precluded from reaching the central $r=0$ singularity. In this paper, we investigate the shadows produced by this geometry to identify deviations from the standard Schwarzschild solution. Our analysis reveals an excess intensity in the inner shadow region that points to a potential observational signature of the novel behavior of light rays propagating near the event horizon. This excess could be a probe for horizon-scale modifications of black hole geometries. Furthermore, although the horizon surface of the Lorentzian-Euclidean black hole continuously accumulates photons and energy, we show that its backreaction response differs from that of stable light rings found in various exotic compact objects.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the shadows of Lorentzian-Euclidean black holes, finding an excess intensity in the inner shadow that may indicate horizon-scale modifications. It also differentiates their backreaction from exotic compact objects.
AI.motivation: To identify observational signatures of geodesically complete spacetimes with signature shifts at event horizons, specifically deviations from the Schwarzschild solution.
AI.method: Analyzing light ray propagation and shadow properties of Lorentzian-Euclidean black holes to observe differences from standard Schwarzschild shadows and backreaction responses.
AI.result: Excess intensity in inner shadow region and distinct backreaction behavior compared to exotic compact objects with stable light rings.
AI.conclusion: The observed excess intensity could serve as an observational probe for modified black hole geometries, offering a test for horizon-scale spacetime models.

title: The test and calibration system for the Elementary Cells of the Cherenkov Camera in the PBR Mission
summary: The development of detectors using Silicon Photo-Multipliers for acquisition of fast light signals coming from Cherenkov and fluorescence emissions started by particle showers in the terrestrial atmosphere is the main goal of the Italian ASI/INFN Agreement n.2021-8-HH.2-2022, named "ASI/INFN_EUSO-SPB2", in view of the next generation of telescopes in balloon-borne and space-based experiments. A survey of performances of different Silicon Photo-Multipliers available on the market has been performed to identify the best sensors for space applications, where high thermal excursions and environmental radiation must be mainly taken into account in contrast to ground-based experiments. In particular, a characterization protocol for Silicon Photo-Multiplier qualification has been specified to Hamamatsu S13161-3050AE-08 sensor ($8 \times 8$) array in the $30 \, \textrm{C}^{\circ}$ down to $-40 \, \textrm{C}^{\circ}$ temperature range. The protocol specifies measurements of break-down voltage, quenching resistance, gain, dark count rate and the probability of cross-talk. These parameters have been measured as a function of temperature at fixed over-voltage. Based on these previous measurements, a dedicated set-up is under completion for performing massive tests to validate and calibrate 32 Silicon Photo-Multipliers (Hamamatsu S13361-3050 series, 64 channels each), composing the (2048 pixels, $12^{\circ} \times 6^{\circ}$ field of view) Focal Surface of the Cherenkov Camera that will fly on the POEMMA-Balloon with Radio mission. The technical details and description of this system and the procedural steps implemented are reported, preliminary measurements on the first Elementary Cell are also shown.

AI.tldr: The paper details the development and testing of Silicon Photo-Multipliers (SiPMs) for use in next-generation balloon-borne telescopes, specifically the POEMMA-Balloon mission, focusing on performance under extreme temperatures and radiation.
AI.motivation: To select and qualify high-performance SiPMs for space applications, addressing challenges like thermal extremes and radiation exposure not typically faced in ground-based experiments.
AI.method: Performed a survey of available SiPMs, developed a characterization protocol for Hamamatsu S13161-3050AE-08 sensors, measuring parameters like breakdown voltage, gain, and dark count rate across temperatures from 30°C to -40°C. A setup is being finalized for testing 32 S13361-3050 series SiPMs for the POEMMA-Balloon's Cherenkov Camera focal surface.
AI.result: Preliminary measurements on an Elementary Cell are presented, though full validation and calibration data of the 2048-pixel camera's performance under space conditions are pending.
AI.conclusion: The protocols and setup demonstrated feasibility for SiPM qualification in harsh space environments, advancing readiness for the POEMMA-Balloon mission's imaging requirements.

title: Maximizing Returns: Optimizing Experimental Observables at the LHC
summary: We introduce a framework that integrates both analytical and machine-learning approaches for calculating observables optimal for EFT and broader applications at the LHC. A new metric for evaluating the performance of these approaches has been introduced. In addition, we demonstrate how the majority of relevant information can be effectively stored in a limited number of bins, allowing for efficient data analysis, data preservation, and global data combination, while also providing tools to achieve these benefits. A key feature of this approach is the reduction in the dimensionality of the observable information, which enhances both the effectiveness and practicality of the data analysis while maximizing gains within limited resources. These features have been demonstrated through simulated analyses of the Higgs boson production and decay processes at the LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a framework combining analytical and machine-learning methods to optimize observables for Effective Field Theories (EFT) and LHC applications. It introduces a new performance metric and demonstrates efficient data analysis by reducing dimensionality through limited bins, validated via Higgs boson simulations.
AI.motivation: To develop an efficient method for calculating optimal observables in EFT and LHC analyses, addressing the need for effective data preservation, global data combination, and resource optimization.
AI.method: The framework integrates analytical techniques with machine learning, uses a new metric to evaluate performance, and employs dimensionality reduction by storing information in a limited number of bins.
AI.result: Successful demonstration through Higgs boson production and decay simulations, showing efficient data handling, preservation, and combination while maximizing gains under resource constraints.
AI.conclusion: The approach effectively enhances data analysis efficiency and practicality in high-energy physics, offering a scalable solution for optimizing observables in EFT and LHC experiments.

title: POLAMI Multi-Wavelength Polarization Study of AGN Jets: A Millimeter-Optical Comparison
summary: Millimeter-band polarimetry offers a powerful probe of AGN jets, accessing regions less affected by opacity and Faraday rotation than at longer radio wavelengths. As part of the POLAMI program, we have conducted 14 years of 1 mm and 3 mm polarization monitoring of a sample of gamma-ray-bright blazars with the IRAM 30-m telescope, complemented here with long-term optical polarimetric observations from multiple facilities. We aim to test whether current models of parsec-scale jet physics are consistent with observed multi-band polarization behavior. Using a Bayesian framework, we derive intrinsic mean flux densities and modulation indices for total flux and fractional polarization, and characterize EVPA variability using circular statistics. We then examine how these quantities reflecting variability properties across millimeter and optical bands relate to synchrotron peak frequency, jet orientation, and radio/gamma-ray luminosities. BL Lac objects exhibit, on average, higher fractional polarization and lower EVPA variability than FSRQs at all wavelengths. Fractional polarization increases with frequency, consistent with increasingly ordered magnetic fields at shorter wavelengths. BL Lacs also show more frequent alignment of EVPAs between optical and millimeter bands, whereas FSRQs display weaker coherence. EVPA variability correlates positively with radio and gamma-ray luminosities and negatively with synchrotron peak frequency, most strongly in the optical. We further find a positive correlation between EVPA spread and fractional polarization variability, suggesting a direct link between magnetic-field structure and polarization dynamics.

AI.tldr: The study uses 14 years of millimeter- and optical-polarization data from blazars to investigate jet physics models, revealing differences between BL Lac and FSRQ objects, and finding correlations between polarization properties and luminosities/synchrotron frequencies.
AI.motivation: To test if current parsec-scale jet physics models align with observed multi-wavelength polarization behavior in AGN jets.
AI.method: 14-year 1/3 mm polarization monitoring with IRAM 30-m telescope, combined with optical data. Bayesian analysis determined flux densities, polarization modulations, and EVPA variability via circular statistics. Correlated results with synchrotron peak frequency, jet orientation, and luminosities.
AI.result: BL Lacs show higher polarization, lower EVPA variability than FSRQs; polarization increases with frequency. EVPA alignment stronger in BL Lacs. EVPA variability correlates with radio/gamma luminosities and inversely with synchrotron peak frequency. Positive link found between EVPA spread and polarization variability.
AI.conclusion: Observed polarization dynamics support models where magnetic field structure influences emission variability. BL Lac/FSRQ differences suggest distinct jet geometry or magnetic configurations. Correlations imply luminosity/magnetic field ordering affect polarization properties.

title: Trilinear Kernel Structure and Its Gravitational Realization
summary: We clarify the structural role of trilinear kernels in multidimensional integrable hierarchies and in stationary axisymmetric gravity. The Yu--Toda--Fukuyama (YTF) trilinear equation of Ref.~\cite{YuTodaSasaFukuyama:1998hierarchy} is shown to represent not a particular evolution equation but a universal kernel that generates the entire $(3+1)$--dimensional hierarchy by selecting commuting flows. The frequently quoted trilinear equation of Ref.~\cite{YTSF1998} is identified as one such flow of this kernel. We further show that stationary axisymmetric gravity corresponds to a projective realization of the YTF kernel rather than to any single flow. Imposing $\GL(2)$ covariance and homogeneity on the kernel leads uniquely to a gravitational trilinear kernel $\mathcal{Y}(τ_0,τ_1)$, whose vanishing reproduces the Ernst equation. The Tomimatsu--Sato family \cite{Tomimatsu1972} and related bilinear solutions are shown to arise as degenerate submanifolds of this projected trilinear structure, in agreement with the multilinear analysis of Ref.~\cite{Fukuyama:2025TS}. These results establish a unified structural framework linking multidimensional trilinear integrability, stationary gravity, and bilinear solution sectors, and clarify why trilinear kernels are both necessary and sufficient for describing soliton dynamics with projective geometry.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes a unified framework connecting multidimensional trilinear integrability, stationary axisymmetric gravity, and bilinear solutions through trilinear kernels. It shows the YTF trilinear equation is a universal kernel generating hierarchies and links it to the Ernst equation and Tomimatsu-Sato solutions.
AI.motivation: To clarify the structural role of trilinear kernels in integrable hierarchies and gravity, demonstrating their necessity and sufficiency for describing soliton dynamics with projective geometry.
AI.method: Analysis of the Yu-Toda-Fukuyama (YTF) trilinear equation as a universal kernel, showing its role in generating (3+1)-D hierarchies and its connection to stationary axisymmetric gravity via projective realizations. Imposition of GL(2) covariance and homogeneity leads to a gravitational trilinear kernel linked to the Ernst equation. Examination of Tomimatsu-Sato solutions as degenerate submanifolds.
AI.result: Establishment of a unified framework where trilinear kernels underpin integrable hierarchies and gravity. The YTF equation is a kernel, not just a flow. The gravitational trilinear kernel uniquely derives the Ernst equation. Tomimatsu-Sato solutions emerge from this structure.
AI.conclusion: Trilinear kernels are essential for describing the integrability of multidimensional systems and gravitational structures, unifying soliton dynamics and projective geometry through their hierarchical and geometric properties.

title: Mobile Intensity Interferometer for Stellar Observations (MI$^2$SO)
summary: In recent years, intensity interferometry has seen renewed interest and successful application at Imaging Atmospheric Cherenkov Telescope arrays. These measurements are usually performed during bright moon periods while the instruments' primary purpose -- gamma-ray observations -- cannot be fulfilled. The Mobile Intensity Interferometer for Stellar Observations was designed as a proof of concept for a purpose-built intensity interferometer. Using acrylic Fresnel lenses 1 m in diameter with 1.2 m focal length, a compact, economical and lightweight design was realised. The detector fixture allows for translation in the z-axis to adjust for measurements at different wavelengths (and therefore focal points) and easy swapping of the detector in its entirety. Both mobility and scalability in quantity of this design allow for specific targeting of projected baselines and orientations based on the target. Particularly for potential binary systems, selective coverage of a target's u-v plane is essential to probing the characteristics accurately. A first campaign demonstrated the capability of these Fresnel lens telescopes by measuring the spatial coherence curve of Arcturus ($α$ Boo). In an observation time of less than 11 h, the angular diameter was measured with milliarcsecond precision, in agreement with the values in the literature.

AI.tldr: The Mobile Intensity Interferometer for Stellar Observations (MIISO) was developed as a cost-effective, portable system using Fresnel lenses to perform stellar intensity interferometry, demonstrating successful measurement of Arcturus' angular diameter with high precision during a preliminary campaign.
AI.motivation: To create a purpose-built, scalable, and mobile intensity interferometer that can efficiently operate during non-optimal gamma-ray observation periods (e.g., bright moon), enabling targeted studies of stellar characteristics like binary systems' u-v plane coverage.
AI.method: Utilizes 1m-diameter acrylic Fresnel lenses with 1.2m focal length, adjustable z-axis detector positioning for wavelength-dependent focal adjustments, and modular detector design. The system was tested by measuring Arcturus' spatial coherence curve to determine angular diameter.
AI.result: Successfully measured Arcturus' angular diameter with milliarcsecond precision in under 11 hours, aligning with established literature values.
AI.conclusion: MIISO validates the feasibility of compact, mobile Fresnel lens-based interferometry for high-precision stellar measurements, offering flexibility in baseline/target selection and cost-effective scalability for future astrophysical studies.

title: Topic Modeling in New Physics Detection
summary: In this work, we apply topic modeling to detect new physics in proton-proton collisions at the LHC in an unsupervised way. We investigate three new physics scenarios where fully leptonic $t\bar{t}\to b\bar{b}\ell^+\ell^-ν_\ell\barν_\ell$ is the main source of background without relying on jet substructure variables. We demonstrate that the algorithm remains effective even in this low-particle multiplicity framework, complementing jet tagging studies, where it is typically employed. Moreover, we demonstrate that the performance of topic modeling is competitive or even better than well-known outlier detectors, such as isolation forest and variational autoencoders, with moderate and high background pollution in almost all new physics scenarios considered.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the use of topic modeling to identify new physics in proton-proton LHC collisions, showing it can effectively detect signals against tt¯ background without jet substructure variables, outperforming isolation forest and VAE methods in most scenarios.
AI.motivation: To develop an unsupervised method (topic modeling) for new physics detection in low-particle multiplicity environments where traditional jet tagging may struggle, particularly in tt¯ background-dominated scenarios.
AI.method: Apply topic modeling to analyze event features in proton-proton collisions, focusing on fully leptonic tt¯ events as background. Compare performance against isolation forest and variational autoencoder outlier detectors.
AI.result: Topic modeling performs comparably or better than baseline methods in detecting new physics signals, even with high background pollution, demonstrating robustness in low-particle multiplicity settings.
AI.conclusion: Topic modeling offers a viable alternative to traditional jet substructure methods, providing competitive performance in unsupervised anomaly detection for new physics searches at the LHC.

title: From a Network to a Networking: The Evolution of the Latin American Giant Observatory
comment: Submitted to the 12th International Workshop on Ring Imaging Cherenkov Detectors (RICH2025)
summary: The Latin American Giant Observatory (LAGO) is a collaborative initiative that deploys a network of low-cost, autonomous Water Cherenkov Detectors across Latin America and Spain. Initially focused on detecting gamma-ray bursts at high-altitude sites, LAGO has evolved into a multidisciplinary forum for astroparticle physics, space weather studies, and environmental monitoring. Its detectors operate from sea level to over 4300 meters above sea level (m a.s.l.) in diverse geomagnetic and atmospheric conditions. The ARTI-MEIGA simulation framework is a key development that models the entire cosmic-ray interaction chain, enabling site-specific simulations to be integrated into FAIR-compliant workflows. LAGO also plays a significant role in regional education and training through partnerships with ERASMUS+ projects, positioning itself as a hub for research capacity building. New contributions emerging from the collaboration include volcano muography, neutron hydrometry for precision agriculture, and space weather monitoring in the South Atlantic Magnetic Anomaly. LAGO demonstrates how Cherenkov-based detection and open science can drive scientific discovery and practical innovation.

AI.tldr: The LAGO project uses affordable water Cherenkov detectors across diverse locations for astroparticle physics, space weather, and environmental monitoring. Their ARTI-MEIGA simulations and collaborations enhance research and education, pioneering applications like volcano imaging and agricultural neutron hydrometry.
AI.motivation: To create an affordable, collaborative platform for multi-disciplinary astrophysics research while fostering education and innovative practical applications in regions with varied environmental conditions.
AI.method: Deploying low-cost autonomous detectors at varying altitudes and latitudes, using the ARTI-MEIGA simulation framework to model cosmic interactions, and integrating with FAIR workflows. Applies Cherenkov detection for gamma-ray bursts and extends to novel uses like muography and neutron analysis.
AI.result: Successfully established a transcontinental network, developed key simulation tools, and pioneered applications in volcano monitoring, agriculture, and space weather. Strengthened regional scientific collaboration and education through EU partnerships.
AI.conclusion: LAGO shows that affordable Cherenkov detection combined with open science can drive both fundamental discoveries and real-world solutions, making it a model for international research collaboration in resource-constrained regions.

title: Gravitational perturbations of nonlocal black holes
comment: 12 pages, accepted for publication in Physical Review D
summary: We derive the master equations governing axial and polar gravitational perturbations of a generic static and spherically symmetric black hole spacetime within the framework of the revised Deser--Woodard nonlocal gravity theory. We then apply our general formalism to a one-parameter family of black hole solutions recently obtained by the present authors, representing small first-order deviations from the Schwarzschild geometry. We provide well-motivated arguments that allow us to render the analysis analytically tractable. Our results provide the first complete perturbative characterization of nonlocal black holes and lay the groundwork for future investigations.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes gravitational perturbations around nonlocal gravity black holes using master equations, focusing on deviations from Schwarzschild geometry.
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of gravitational perturbations in Deser-Woodard nonlocal gravity and validate the stability of nonlocal black hole solutions.
AI.method: Derive master equations for axial and polar perturbations in nonlocal gravity, apply to a one-parameter family of black holes with small Schwarzschild deviations, using analytical simplifications.
AI.result: First complete perturbative characterization of nonlocal black holes, enabling future stability and observational studies.
AI.conclusion: The analysis confirms the viability of nonlocal black hole models and establishes a framework for further research in modified gravity theories.

title: Zero-Shot Detection of Elastic Transient Morphology Across Physical Systems
summary:
We test whether a representation learned from interferometric strain transients in gravitational-wave observatories can act as a frozen morphology-sensitive operator for unseen sensors, provided the target signals preserve coherent elastic transient structure. Using a neural encoder trained exclusively on non-Gaussian instrumental glitches, we perform strict zero-shot anomaly analysis on rolling-element bearings without retraining, fine-tuning, or target-domain labels.
  On the IMS-NASA run-to-failure dataset, the operator yields a monotonic health index HI(t) = s0.99(t)/tau normalized to an early-life reference distribution, enabling fixed false-alarm monitoring at 1-q = 1e-3 with tau = Q0.999(P0). In discrete fault regimes (CWRU), it achieves strong window-level discrimination (AUC_win about 0.90) and file-level separability approaching unity (AUC_file about 0.99). Electrically dominated vibration signals (VSB) show weak, non-selective behavior, delineating a physical boundary for transfer.
  Under a matched IMS controlled-split protocol, a generic EfficientNet-B0 encoder pretrained on ImageNet collapses in the intermittent regime (Lambda_tail about 2), while the interferometric operator retains strong extreme-event selectivity (Lambda_tail about 860), indicating that the effect is not a generic property of CNN features. Controlled morphology-destruction transformations selectively degrade performance despite per-window normalization, consistent with sensitivity to coherent time-frequency organization rather than marginal amplitude statistics.

AI.tldr: The paper demonstrates that a neural network trained on gravitational-wave observatory glitches can detect anomalies in unseen sensors like rolling-element bearings without retraining, achieving high performance in specific regimes and highlighting the importance of coherent transient structure.
AI.motivation: To explore if learned representations from gravitational-wave data can be transferred for anomaly detection in mechanical systems, leveraging the preservation of coherent elastic transient structures across domains.
AI.method: A neural encoder trained on non-Gaussian glitches from gravitational-wave observatories is applied in a zero-shot manner to bearing datasets (IMS-NASA, CWRU, VSB). Performance is evaluated via health indices and AUC scores, with controlled experiments to test morphology sensitivity.
AI.result: The method shows strong performance in IMS-NASA (monotonic health index) and CWRU (AUC_win ~0.90, AUC_file ~0.99), weaker results in VSB. Compared to a generic EfficientNet, the interferometric operator retains better extreme-event selectivity under controlled splits.
AI.conclusion: The success stems from the operator's sensitivity to coherent time-frequency morphology, not generic CNN features. This cross-domain anomaly detection is effective when target signals preserve relevant physical structures, offering a new approach for unobserved sensor systems.

title: The Sensitivity of Higgs Factories to Composite Higgs Models via Precision Measurements
summary: We investigate the potential of precision Higgs factory measurements to discover signatures of a representative model of electroweak symmetry breaking in which the Higgs boson arises as a composite Nambu-Goldstone boson. In this model, as in other models of the ``Little Higgs" or Natural Composite Higgs type, the primary perturbations of the Standard Model come from effects of vectorlike top quark partners. We carry out an explicit calculation of the Higgs potential in this model. Applying phenomenological constraints, we are left with a 3-dimensional parameter space. We then present results from a complete scan of this parameter space. The region in which significant departures from the Standard Model predictions extends to models in which the lightest top quark partner has a mass above 3~TeV. Little Higgs models with such heavy top partners also predict significant deviations from the Standard Model in the top quark electroweak couplings, in particular, in the model studied here, in the $t_L$ coupling to the $Z$ boson.

AI.tldr: The paper explores how precision Higgs measurements at a future Higgs factory can detect signatures of a composite Higgs model (Little Higgs/Composite Higgs type), showing significant deviations from the Standard Model even when top partners are as heavy as 3 TeV, affecting top-Z couplings.
AI.motivation: To investigate if precision Higgs factory measurements can uncover signals of a composite Higgs model, which provides an alternative to the Standard Model's Higgs mechanism, by studying effects from heavy vectorlike top partners.
AI.method:
1. Calculated the Higgs potential in the model
2. Applied phenomenological constraints to reduce parameter space to 3 dimensions
3. Performed a complete parameter space scan
4. Analyzed deviations in Higgs properties and top quark electroweak couplings
AI.result: 发现了在顶夸克伙伴质量超过3TeV时仍存在明显超出SM的预测区域。这些模型预测了顶夸克弱相互作用规范耦合（特别是左旋顶夸克与Z玻色子的耦合）的显著偏离。
AI.conclusion: Precision Higgs factory measurements are essential for probing composite Higgs models with heavy top partners (up to 3 TeV), which exhibit measurable deviations in both Higgs properties and top-Z couplings beyond the Standard Model predictions.

title: The Deeper, Wider, Faster programme's first DECam optical data release
comment: 16 pages, 9 figures, 7 tables, published in PASA
summary: The transient and variable optical sky is relatively poorly characterised on fast ($<$1$\,$hr) timescales. With the Dark Energy Camera (DECam), the Deeper, Wider, Faster programme (DWF) probes a unique parameter space with its deep (median of $g\sim22.2$ AB mag), minute-cadence imaging. In this work, we present DWF's first data release which comprises high cadence photometry extracted from $\sim$12000 images and 166 hours of telescope time. We present a novel data processing pipeline, $\texttt{dwf-postpipe}$, developed to identify sources and extract their light curves. The accuracy of the photometry is assessed by cross-matching to public catalogues. In addition, we injected a population of synthetic GRB afterglows into a subset of the DWF DECam imaging to compare the efficiency of our pipeline with a standard difference imaging approach. Both pipelines show performance and reliably recover injected transients with peak magnitudes $g<22$ AB mag with an efficiency of $97.24^{+0.7}_{-1.0}$ percent for \texttt{dwf-postpipe} and $96.14^{+0.9}_{-1.1}$ percent for a difference imaging approach. However, we find that $\texttt{dwf-postpipe}$ is less likely to recover transients appearing in galaxies that are brighter or comparable in brightness to the transient itself. To demonstrate the power of the data in this release, we conduct a search for uncatalogued variable stars in a single night of DWF DECam imaging and find ten pulsating variables, two eclipsing binaries and one ZZ ceti. We also conduct a search for variable phenomena in the Chandra Deep Field South, a Rubin deep drilling field, and identify two flares from likely UV ceti type stars.

AI.tldr: The paper presents the first data release from the DWF program using DECam, featuring high-cadence photometry and a new pipeline (dwf-postpipe). Comparisons with difference imaging show similar efficiency (97.24% vs. 96.14%) in detecting transients, with limitations in brighter galaxy contexts. The data revealed variable stars and stellar flares.
AI.motivation: The transient optical sky on fast timescales (<1hr) is under-studied. DWF addresses this gap with deep, minute-cadence imaging to explore this parameter space.
AI.method: Developed dwf-postpipe for source detection and light curve extraction. Cross-matched with public catalogs for accuracy. Simulated GRB afterglows to compare with difference imaging methods.
AI.result: Released ~12,000 images from 166 hours of observation. Recovered 97.24% (dwf-postpipe) and 96.14% (difference imaging) of injected transients, but struggled with bright galaxies. Identified variable stars and stellar flares in observed fields.
AI.conclusion: DWF's high-cadence data and pipeline enable effective transient detection, though challenges remain in bright source environments. The dataset highlights potential for discovering variable phenomena and validates the methodology's utility in future studies.

title: Analytic self-force effects on radial infalling particles in the Schwarzschild spacetime: the radiated energy
summary: We compute, at the first self force accuracy level, the radiated energy from a radially infalling particle released from rest in a Schwarzschild spacetime. We examine both the cases of a scalar particle and that of a massive particle, in the context of gravitational perturbations. Our findings are accompanied by Post-Newtonian checks. In spite of the specific interest for this kind of computations, we outline the building blocks for future higher-order Post-Newtonian computations as well as for extending these results to other interesting situations out of the black hole case.

AI.tldr: The paper calculates the radiated energy from a radially infalling particle in Schwarzschild spacetime using first-order self-force methods, examines scalar and massive particles in gravitational perturbations, and discusses extensions for future work.
AI.motivation: To compute radiated energy for particles moving in black hole spacetimes, validate results with post-Newtonian approximations, and establish a framework for higher-order calculations and broader applications.
AI.method: First-order self-force techniques applied to Schwarzschild spacetime; analyzes both scalar and massive particles within gravitational perturbation theory, with post-Newtonian checks.
AI.result: Quantitative results for energy radiation from infalling particles, validated against post-Newtonian predictions; identifies foundational elements for extending computations to more complex scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Highlights the success of self-force methods in this context and emphasizes the importance of these results for future higher-order post-Newtonian studies and applications beyond black holes.

title: Five Years of Mini-EUSO Observations from the ISS: Summary of Key Results
summary: Mini-EUSO is the first space-borne detector of the JEM-EUSO (Joint Exploratory Missions for Extreme Universe Space Observatory) program, operating on the International Space Station (ISS) since October 2019. Designed to search for Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays (UHECRs) above 10$^{21}~$eV and capable of placing a stringent upper limit on their flux at these extreme energies, paving the way to future space-based UHECR observatories, Mini-EUSO has completed more than 150 observation sessions over five years, accumulating approximately 750 hours of data. The mission has produced the first global UV emission maps of Earth and provided valuable insights into lightning phenomena and Transient Luminous Events (TLEs), such as elves, as well as artificial light sources and meteors. Notably, Mini-EUSO has conducted the first systematic space-based meteor survey, detecting over 22,000 meteors and identifying three interstellar candidates. Among the observed TLEs, the most interesting class of phenomena are elves, which appear as expanding ring-shaped structures occurring at $\sim$90 km altitude. Mini-EUSO has detected elves with varying structures and different numbers of concentric rings, from single-ring up to five rings. Thanks to its imaging capabilities, fast time resolution, and favorable observational geometry, Mini-EUSO is uniquely suited to studying this kind of lightning phenomena, providing unprecedented insight into their dynamics. Additionally, the instrument has demonstrated the capability of a space-based detector to identify short light transients resembling extensive air shower signals while distinguishing them from those produced by UHECRs. This contribution presents a comprehensive summary of the Mini-EUSO mission, its status, and main results.

AI.tldr: Mini-EUSO is the first space-based detector in the JEM-EUSO program, operating on the ISS since 2019. It has gathered extensive data on UHECRs, produced global UV maps, studied TLEs (especially elves with multi-ring structures), and identified interstellar meteor candidates while distinguishing air showers from UHECR signals. These achievements lay groundwork for future cosmic ray observatories.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to explore Ultra-High Energy Cosmic Rays (UHECRs) beyond 10^21 eV and validate space-based detection techniques, while investigating transient phenomena like elves and meteors to understand atmospheric dynamics and pave the way for advanced detectors.
AI.method: Mini-EUSO uses UV imaging with rapid time resolution and optimal geometry to detect UHECR-induced extensive air showers, track meteors, and analyze TLEs. Data from 150+ ISS observation sessions over 750 hours enabled systematic surveys, including the first space-based meteor census and detailed elf structure analysis.
AI.result: Observed over 22,000 meteors (3 interstellar candidates), created first global UV Earth maps, detected elves with up to five concentric rings, and established methods to differentiate UHECR signals from other transients. Demonstrated capabilities critical for future space-based UHECR observatories.
AI.conclusion: Mini-EUSO successfully achieved its objectives, providing key data on UHECR limits, meteor dynamics, and TLE behavior. Its results validate space-based detection potential and set foundational standards for upcoming missions targeting extreme universe phenomena.

title: Spectral Signatures of Heavy Quarkonia in a Rotating and Anisotropic Quark-Gluon Plasma: A Holographic Study
summary: We investigate the in-medium spectral functions and effective masses of heavy quarkonia charmonium ($J/Ψ$) and bottomonium ($Υ(1S)$) in a quark-gluon plasma (QGP) possessing both global rotation and spatial anisotropy. Using a gauge/gravity holographic model incorporating finite temperature, chemical potential, and warp factor, we compute the spectral signatures non-perturbatively. Our results show that both rotation and anisotropy enhance quarkonium dissociation, manifesting as peak suppression and width broadening in the spectral functions. Crucially, their effects are directional: anisotropy primarily dissociates longitudinally polarized states, while rotation more strongly disrupts transversely polarized ones. A competitive interplay exists: for small anisotropy, rotational effects dominate at high angular velocity, whereas for large anisotropy, anisotropy governs the dissociation regardless of rotation strength. Furthermore, rotation induces a non-monotonic temperature dependence in the transverse effective mass of $J/Ψ$, while strong anisotropy causes similar non-monotonicity in the longitudinal effective mass of $J/Ψ$. These findings reveal how the distinct symmetry breaking patterns induced by QGP rotation and anisotropy reshape the heavy quarkonium spectrum, providing new insights into polarization-dependent suppression in non-central heavy-ion collisions.

AI.tldr: The study explores how a rotating and spatially anisotropic quark-gluon plasma affects heavy quarkonia (charmonium and bottomonium) using a holographic model. Results show enhanced dissociation due to rotation and anisotropy, with direction-dependent effects on polarization states and effective masses.
AI.motivation: To understand the impact of QGP's rotation and spatial anisotropy on quarkonium dissociation, which is crucial for interpreting heavy-ion collision experiments, particularly regarding polarization-dependent suppression in non-central collisions.
AI.method: Employed a gauge/gravity holographic model with finite temperature, chemical potential, and warp factor to non-perturbatively compute spectral functions and effective masses for J/ψ and Υ(1S) in an anisotropic, rotating QGP.
AI.result: Rotation and anisotropy enhance dissociation through peak suppression and broadening in spectral functions. Anisotropy dissociates longitudinal states more, while rotation affects transverse states. Competitive effects emerge where rotation dominates at high speeds for small anisotropy, while strong anisotropy remains dominant. Non-monotonic temperature dependencies in effective masses were observed.
AI.conclusion: The distinct symmetry-breaking from QGP rotation and anisotropy significantly reshape quarkonium spectra, offering new insights into polarization-dependent suppression in heavy-ion collisions, highlighting the importance of considering both effects in experimental analysis.

title: X-ray and radio observations of the AMXP MAXI J1957+032 covering the 2022-2025 outbursts
comment: 8 pages, 5 figures, accepted for publication in A&A
summary: We presented a comprehensive multi-epoch timing and multiwavelength analysis of the accreting millisecond X-ray pulsar MAXI J1957+032, covering two major outbursts in 2022 and 2025. By reanalyzing the 2022 outburst data from the Neutron Star Interior Composition Explorer (NICER), we found the spin frequency and orbital parameters from the observations in 0.3-5 keV. For the 2025 outburst, we reported the detection of pulsations with the Einstein Probe (EP). Based on the $\sim$3-year baseline between these two outbursts, we measured a significant long-term spin-down rate of $\dotν= (-5.73 \pm 0.28) \times 10^{-14}~{\rm Hz~s^{-1}}$. Assuming that the quiescent spin-down is driven by magnetic dipole radiation, we inferred a spin-down luminosity of $L \approx 1.1 \times 10^{36}~{\rm erg~s^{-1}}$ and a surface dipolar magnetic field of $B \approx (7.3 - 10.4) \times 10^8$ G. Furthermore, we conducted a deep radio pulsation search with the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) during the X-ray quiescent state in 2024, resulting in a non-detection with a 7$σ$ flux density upper limit of 12.3 $μ$Jy. This corresponds to a radio efficiency upper limit of $ξ< 2.8 \times 10^{-10}$, which is significantly lower than that of typical millisecond pulsars with a similar spin-down power. This profound radio pulsation faintness can be explained by two primary scenarios: either a geometric effect, wherein the pulsar's radio beam is directed away from our line of sight, or a physical suppression of the emission mechanism, potentially caused by a persistent low-level accretion flow during the X-ray quiescent state.

AI.tldr: The study analyzes the accreting millisecond X-ray pulsar MAXI J1957+032 across two outbursts, revealing a significant spin-down rate, magnetic field constraints, and a non-detection in radio searches, suggesting geometric or physical emission suppression.
AI.motivation: To investigate the long-term evolutionary behavior and emission properties of MAXI J1957+032, particularly its spin evolution and radio emission characteristics during outbursts and quiescence.
AI.method: Multi-epoch NICER timing and EP observations during 2022/2025 outbursts; measurement of spin & orbital parameters, spin-down rate. FAST radio search during 2024 quiescence for pulsation detection limits.
AI.result: Measured spin-down rate of ~-5.73e-14 Hz/s; inferred L~1e36 erg/s and B~7.3-10.4e8 G. FAST found no radio pulsations (upper limit 12.3 μJy), yielding ξ<2.8e-10, much lower than typical millisecond pulsars.
AI.conclusion: The radio faintness is likely due to either a misaligned radio beam or suppressed emission from residual accretion during quiescence, providing insights into neutron star magnetospheric physics and accretion processes.

title: Rapid inference of gravitational-wave signals in the time domain using a heterodyned likelihood
summary: Parameter estimation of gravitational wave signals is computationally intensive and typically requires millions of likelihood evaluations to construct posterior probability distributions. This computational cost increases significantly in the time domain, which requires non-diagonal covariance matrices to compute the likelihood. Consequently, parameter estimation of long-duration gravitational wave signals, such as binary neutron star mergers, becomes computationally infeasible in time domain. In this work, we detail a framework for the heterodyned likelihood that enables rapid inference in the time domain. Our method is applicable to signals with arbitrary mode content, and leverages the smoothness of the ratio of complex-valued waveform modes, approximating the ratio as a linear function within appropriately chosen time bins. This allows downsampling of the waveform modes and a reformulation of the likelihood, such that it depends only on the bin edges. We demonstrate that this likelihood recovers posteriors that are indistinguishable from those obtained using the standard likelihood in the time domain. We also observe dramatic improvement in speed - for a 128 seconds-long gravitational wave signal, our method is at least $\sim 400$ times faster than the standard time-domain analysis, reducing the wall clock time to just a few hours. We also demonstrate the reliability and unbiasedness of the likelihood using percentile-percentile tests for binary black hole and binary neutron star injections. We use the Gohberg-Semencul representation of the inverse of Toeplitz covariance matrix to accelerate matrix-vector products, which has potential applications even in non heterodyned time-domain inference.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a framework for heterodyned likelihood to speed up gravitational wave parameter estimation in the time domain, achieving a ~400x speedup for 128-second signals while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: The computational expense of time-domain parameter estimation for long gravitational wave signals, like binary neutron star mergers, is prohibitive due to non-diagonal covariance matrices requiring millions of likelihood evaluations.
AI.method: The framework uses the smoothness of waveform mode ratios, approximating them linearly within time bins to downsample modes and reformulate the likelihood dependent only on bin edges. It employs the Gohberg-Semencul formula for efficient Toeplitz matrix inversion.
AI.result: The method produces posteriors indistinguishable from standard time-domain analysis with a ~400x speed improvement, reducing runtime to a few hours for 128-second signals. Reliability and unbiasedness are confirmed via percentile tests.
AI.conclusion: The heterodyned likelihood enables computationally feasible time-domain analysis for long gravitational wave signals, offering substantial speed gains without compromising accuracy. The Gohberg-Semencul approach also benefits non-heterodyned time-domain methods.

title: Spectroscopy of $ρ$-meson in symmetric nuclear medium
summary: In this work, we investigate the behavior of the light vector \(ρ\) meson in the presence of a symmetric nuclear medium at zero temperature. We calculate the mass and decay constant of the $ρ$-meson as well as the leading twist distribution amplitudes (DAs) in the light-front quark model in vacuum, which are further investigated at different baryonic densities. We also predict the Mellin moments of the DAs and decay width of the $ρ^0 \to e^+ e^-$ process in both vacuum and medium. The evolution of DAs is carried out by the leading order (LO) Efremov-Radyushkin-Brodsky-Lepage method and compared with available predictions. For better understanding of medium effects on $ρ$-meson, we have also predicted the in-medium charge ($G_C(Q^2)$), magnetic ($G_M(Q^2)$), and quadrupole ($G_Q(Q^2)$) form factors. The in-medium charge radii, magnetic moment, and quadrupole moment have also been predicted in this work. We have found that the nuclear medium induces appreciable modifications on the mass, weak decay constant, decay width, and distribution amplitudes of the \(ρ\) meson. However, the charge radii, magnetic moment, and quadrupole moment are observed to exhibit weaker sensitivity to changes in baryonic density.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the behavior of the ρ meson in a symmetric nuclear medium at zero temperature, focusing on its mass, decay constant, distribution amplitudes, and form factors. Significant medium-induced modifications are observed in mass, decay properties, and DAs, while charge/magnetic moments show weaker sensitivity.
AI.motivation: To understand how nuclear medium effects alter the properties of ρ mesons, which is crucial for interpreting nucleon resonance experiments and medium modifications in quantum chromodynamics (QCD).
AI.method: Light-front quark model calculations in vacuum and medium. Predictions include Mellin moments, decay widths (ρ⁰ → e⁺e⁻), and form factors (charge, magnetic, quadrupole) using LO Efremov-Radyushkin-Brodsky-Lepage evolution method.
AI.result: ρ meson mass, decay constant, and DAs show significant sensitivity to baryonic density. Charge radii, magnetic/quadrupole moments exhibit weaker dependence on medium density.
AI.conclusion: Nuclear medium substantially modifies key properties of ρ mesons, highlighting the importance of medium effects in QCD studies. Results provide benchmarks for future experiments and theoretical models.

title: Radiative Cooling Effects on Plasmoid Formation in Black Hole Accretion Flows with Multiple Magnetic Loops
summary: Context. We investigate the physics of black hole accretion flows, particularly focusing on phenomena like magnetic reconnection and plasmoid formation, which are believed to be responsible for energetic events such as flares observed from astrophysical black holes.Aims. We aim to understand the influence of radiative cooling on plasmoid formation within black hole accretion flows that are threaded by multi-loop magnetic field configurations.Methods. We conducted two- and three-dimensional two-temperature general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations. By varying the magnetic loop sizes and the mass accretion rate, we explored how radiative cooling alters the accretion dynamics, disk structure, and the properties of reconnection-driven plasmoid chains.Results. Our results demonstrate that radiative cooling suppresses the transition to the magnetically arrested disk (MAD) state by reducing magnetic flux accumulation near the horizon. It significantly modifies the disk morphology by lowering the electron temperature and compressing the disk, which leads to increased density at the equatorial plane and decreased magnetization. Within the current sheets, radiative cooling triggers layer compression and the collapse of plasmoids, shortening their lifetime and reducing their size, while the frequency of plasmoid events increases. Moreover, we observe enhanced negative energy-at-infinity density in plasmoids near the ergosphere, with its peaks corresponding to plasmoid presence.Conclusions. Radiative cooling plays a critical role in shaping both macroscopic accretion flow properties and microscopic reconnection phenomena near black holes. This suggests that radiative cooling may modulate black hole energy extraction through reconnection-driven Penrose processes, highlighting its importance in models of astrophysical black holes.

AI.tldr: Radiative cooling impacts black hole accretion flows by inhibiting MAD states, altering disk structure, and modifying plasmoid behavior in magnetic reconnection events.
AI.motivation: To understand how radiative cooling affects plasmoid formation and accretion dynamics in black hole systems with multi-loop magnetic fields.
AI.method: 2D and 3D two-temperature GRMHD simulations varying magnetic loop sizes and mass accretion rates to study cooling effects.
AI.result: Radiative cooling suppresses MAD states, reduces horizon magnetic flux, alters disk temperature/density, shrinks plasmoid lifetimes/sizes but increases event frequency, and enhances negative energy-at-infinity in ergosphere plasmoids.
AI.conclusion: Radiative cooling significantly influences both large-scale accretion and reconnection processes, potentially modulating energy extraction via Penrose processes in astrophysical black holes.

title: Source-Driven Tails in Kerr Spacetime: Nonlinear effects in Late-Time Behavior
comment: 7 pages, 2 figures, 3 tables, comments and feedback are welcome
summary:
We present the long-duration time-domain simulations of scalar-field tails in Kerr spacetimes driven by
  \emph{outgoing} multipolar sources. Extending the recent work in the literature from Schwarzschild to rotating black holes, we evolve
  sources with $\ell'=\{0,1,2,3,4\}$ on backgrounds with dimensionless spin $a/M=\{0.0, 0.8, 1.0\}$ and extract the late-time decay rates of
  measured modes $\ell\le4$ for a nonlinearity-inspired outgoing source with a $1/r^2$ fall-off. In all cases we find the inverse
  power-law index $p_{\ell\ell'}$ to be larger than the source-free Price law values by one unit, i.e. $p^{\text{sourced}}_{\ell\ell'} =
  p^{\text{Price}}_{\ell\ell'} + 1$. We also include a power-law index value computation for a similar source-driven gravitational wave
  case $(\ell,m)=(4,4)$ and confirm closely related results in the recent literature.

AI.tldr: The paper presents simulations of scalar-field tails in rotating Kerr spacetimes driven by outgoing multipolar sources, finding that the late-time decay rates (inverse power-law indices) are increased by one unit compared to source-free Price law values.
AI.motivation: Extends previous Schwarzschild spacetime studies to rotating black holes, examining how source-driven effects modify scalar-field tails and validating against gravitational wave results.
AI.method: Long-duration time-domain simulations of scalar fields in Kerr spacetimes with varying spin parameters (a/M = 0.0, 0.8, 1.0) and multipolar sources (ℓ'=0-4), extracting decay rates for modes up to ℓ≤4 using nonlinearity-inspired outgoing sources with 1/r² fall-off.
AI.result: Observed p^sourced_{ℓℓ'} = p^Price_{ℓℓ'}+1 across all tested configurations, consistent with earlier gravitational wave studies for (ℓ,m)=(4,4) cases.
AI.conclusion: Source-driven systems in Kerr spacetimes exhibit predictable deviations from Price's law, confirming the robustness of these decay rate modifications in both scalar and gravitational wave contexts.

title: The properties of strange quark matter and evolution of strange quark stars
summary: In this work, we study the properties of strange quark matter and reveal the evolution process of strange quark stars employing a self consistent thermodynamic treatment. A comprehensive and reliable thermodynamic basis for the study of the dynamic evolution from proto-strange quark stars to stable strange stars at a zero temperature is provided. The relative abundance of particles, equation of state, temperature, and mass-radius relationship at each stage of the evolution of stars are discussed, where the cold strange quark star are consistent with the observational mass and radius of Hess J1731-347, PSR J1231-1411, PSR J0030+0451, PSR J0348+0432, and PSR J0740+6620, which could be difficult to be explained by the standard neutron star model. A schematic diagram is provided as well, illustrating the state of different stages along the evolution of stars at a fixed baryon-mass.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the properties of strange quark matter and the evolution of strange quark stars, providing a thermodynamic framework that aligns with observational data of specific pulsars, challenging the standard neutron star model.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive thermodynamic basis for understanding the evolution of strange quark stars and reconcile theoretical models with observational data of pulsars that neutron star models struggle to explain.
AI.method: Employed a self-consistent thermodynamic treatment to model the dynamic evolution from proto-strange quark stars to stable strange stars at zero temperature, analyzing particle abundance, equation of state, temperature, and mass-radius relationships.
AI.result: The model's predictions for cold strange quark stars match observed masses and radii of pulsars like Hess J1731-347 and PSR J1231-1411, which are inconsistent with neutron star models. A schematic diagram of evolutionary stages at fixed baryon mass is provided.
AI.conclusion: Strange quark stars offer a viable alternative to neutron stars, supported by observational evidence and the developed thermodynamic framework.

title: Curvature Effect on the Speed of Sound
summary: The speed of sound refers to the rate at which information travels from one point to another. It is a positive quantity and bounded by causality. It is defined as the rate of change of pressure with respect to the system's density. In this article, we derive a covariant equation for the sound wave and demonstrate how the wave equation is modified in the general relativistic formalism. One can then define an effective speed of sound by attenuating the usual definition of sound speed with the gravitational metric potential. The general relativistic curvature effect is observed to reduce the speed of sound when computed inside a neutron star. This effectively makes the star relatively softer (according to the equation of state). The change in the effective sound speed can be easily visualised if one redefines the non-radial modes in terms of it. The modes do not change, but the space-time curvature reduces the amplitude of the oscillation modes. The formalism is suited for studying astrophysical compact objects.

AI.tldr: The article derives a covariant equation for sound waves in general relativity, showing that spacetime curvature reduces the effective speed of sound inside neutron stars, leading to a softer equation of state and reduced oscillation amplitudes in non-radial modes.
AI.motivation: To understand how general relativistic effects influence the speed of sound in compact astrophysical objects like neutron stars and their oscillation modes.
AI.method: Derive a covariant wave equation incorporating gravitational metric potentials, redefining the effective sound speed and analyzing non-radial oscillation modes under spacetime curvature.
AI.result: General relativistic curvature decreases the effective sound speed in neutron stars, softening the equation of state and reducing oscillation mode amplitudes.
AI.conclusion: The formalism provides a framework to study relativistic effects on sound propagation and stellar stability in compact objects, important for astrophysical applications.

title: Elliptic flow of charm quarks produced in the early stage of pA collisions
summary: We investigate the build-up of elliptic flow of charm quarks produced in the early pre-equilibrium stage of high-energy proton--nucleus collisions. The initial stage is modeled within the Color Glass Condensate framework as an evolving glasma, initialized through the McLerran--Venugopalan model. Subnucleonic fluctuations have been implemented as constituent-quark hotspots for both the proton and the nuclear participants. Charm quarks are propagated in the evolving non-Abelian background by solving the relativistic Wong equations for their coordinates, momenta, and color charges. First, we compute the nuclear modification factor of charm quarks, finding a slight migration towards higher $p_T$ states in agreement with previous results in the literature. Then, we focus on the azimuthal anisotropies acquired through the interaction with glasma fields. We find that glasma-induced momentum anisotropies are efficiently transmitted to heavy quarks within $τ\sim 0.4~\mathrm{fm/c}$, leading to a sizeable charm-quark $v_2$, with a magnitude that increases with the strength of the initial fields and with the number of nuclear participants. Remarkably, we show that the early-stage contribution alone can account for a significant fraction of the experimentally observed $J/ψ$ elliptic flow in p-Pb collisions, indicating that pre-hydrodynamic dynamics can play a non-negligible role in the final-state heavy-flavor collectivity, especially in small systems.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the development of elliptic flow of charm quarks in the early stages of high-energy proton-nucleus collisions. Using the Color Glass Condensate framework and Wong equations, they show that pre-equilibrium glasma fields induce significant $v_2$ anisotropy in charm quarks, contributing notably to observed $J/ψ$ elliptic flow in p-Pb collisions. This indicates pre-hydrodynamic dynamics are important for heavy-flavor collectivity in small systems.
AI.motivation: To understand the origin of heavy-flavor elliptic flow in small collision systems like p-Pb, focusing on early pre-equilibrium stages before hydrodynamic behavior dominates. Existing models often rely on later hydrodynamic expansion but may miss contributions from early glasma field interactions.
AI.method: Modeling proton-nucleus collisions within the Color Glass Condensate framework, initializing glasma evolution via McLerran-Venugopalan model with quark hotspots. Charm quarks are tracked via relativistic Wong equations in the non-Abelian background field, computing nuclear modification factors and azimuthal anisotropies from glasma interactions.
AI.result: Early glasma interactions generate sizable charm quark $v_2$ within 0.4 fm/c, with magnitude dependent on field strength and participant number. The early-stage contribution alone explains a large fraction of measured $J/ψ$ elliptic flow in p-Pb collisions.
AI.conclusion: Pre-equilibrium glasma dynamics significantly contribute to heavy-flavor collectivity, especially in small systems. This challenges assumptions that hydrodynamic expansion alone drives observables, necessitating combined early and late stage modeling for accurate predictions.

title: An 11-Year Catalog of Gamma-Ray Transients: A Comprehensive Search with Fermi Gamma-ray Burst Monitor Data
comment: 26 pages, 10 figures, 11 tables. Accepted for publication in ApJS
summary: The Gamma-ray Burst Monitor (GBM) on board Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope has produced the largest database of all-sky observations in gamma rays with its continuous data with high time and energy resolutions. These data contain a wealth of unidentified transient events that did not trigger the detectors for various reasons. We conducted extensive searches to identify such untriggered transient events observed with GBM in 11 years (July 2010 - June 2021). In particular, we employed four different search modes with various energy ranges (mainly below 300 keV) and time resolutions (from 8 ms to 2 s), utilizing three statistical methods (signal-to-noise ratio, Poisson, and Bayesian statistics), each with different effectiveness in identifying specific classes of transients. Moreover, we developed algorithms for known-event flagging as well as unknown-event classification for our candidate events found in the searches. In this paper, we present our search methodologies, event flagging and classification algorithms and the resulting comprehensive event catalog. The catalog contains more than a million events in total, including known events such as gamma-ray bursts, soft-gamma repeater bursts, galactic X-ray source activities, terrestrial gamma flashes, and solar flares. For each candidate event, the catalog presents the event time, detection significance, event duration, hardness ratios, known-event flagging results, and classification probabilities. Our short-transient catalog significantly expands the currently-existing list of known events and complements the GBM trigger catalog. The event database with filtering capabilities is also publicly available at https://magnetars.sabanciuniv.edu/gbm, which allows users to retrieve event information based on their input queries along with the event lightcurves.

AI.tldr: The paper describes the development and results of a comprehensive search for untriggered gamma-ray transient events using Fermi GBM data, resulting in a catalog of over a million events classified using multiple statistical methods and algorithms.
AI.motivation: To identify transient events undetected by standard triggers, leveraging GBM's extensive dataset for previously missed phenomena and expanding the known event inventory.
AI.method: Four search modes with variable energy/time parameters, three statistical methods (SNR, Poisson, Bayesian), algorithms for flagging known events and classifying unknowns, creating a catalog with metadata and accessibility features.
AI.result: Catalog contains over a million events, including known classes like GRBs and solar flares, with detailed parameters and classification probabilities. The public database enables user-driven queries and lightcurve access.
