AI.conclusion: This work significantly enhances transient event detection capabilities, supplements existing catalogs, and provides a valuable resource for astrophysical studies through open access.

title: HL-LHC sensitivity to an ultraheavy $S_{uu}$ diquark in the $uχ$ channel
summary: We study the HL-LHC sensitivity to an ultraheavy diquark $S_{uu}$ produced in up-quark fusion and decaying as $S_{uu}\to uχ$, $χ\to Wb, Zt, h^0t$. For fully hadronic decays of the W, Z and top quark, this gives rise to multijet final states. Within the same model framework used previously for the $S_{uu}\toχχ$ six-jet channel, we consider $S_{uu}$ masses in the multi-TeV range and vectorlike quark masses of order a few TeV, and simulate proton-proton collisions at $\sqrt s = 13.6$ TeV with integrated luminosities up to the HL-LHC target. The analysis strategy employs a machine-learning-based discriminant adapted from the six-jet study to the new four-jet topology, which we use to derive the corresponding discovery reaches and exclusion limits. We find that this topology improves the overall sensitivity to $S_{uu}$ in regions where the branching ratio $B(S_{uu}\to uχ)$ is sizable and provides a complementary signature for studying ultraheavy diquarks at the HL-LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper examines the High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC) sensitivity to an ultraheavy diquark S_{uu} through its production via up-quark fusion and decay into uχ, with χ further decaying into Wb, Zt, or h^0t. The focus is on multijet final states, particularly in the four-jet topology. The analysis adapts a machine-learning discriminant from prior six-jet studies to evaluate discovery potential and exclusion limits, showing this channel enhances sensitivity in certain branching ratio scenarios.
AI.motivation: To explore complementary signatures for detecting ultraheavy diquarks at the HL-LHC, improving sensitivity in scenarios where the branching ratio for S_{uu} → uχ is significant. This expands upon previous six-jet channel studies to include multijet final states.
AI.method: Simulations of 13.6 TeV proton-proton collisions with up to HL-LHC luminosity. A machine-learning-based discriminator, adapted from the six-jet analysis, was used to analyze the four-jet topology resulting from fully hadronic decays. Ultraheavy diquark masses (multi-TeV) and vectorlike quark masses (few TeV) were considered within the same theoretical framework as prior work.
AI.result: The four-jet topology improves discovery potential and exclusion limits for S_{uu} in regions with a sizable branching ratio B(S_{uu}→uχ). It provides a complementary signature to existing analyses, enhancing overall sensitivity to ultraheavy diquarks.
AI.conclusion: This topology is crucial for extending the reach of HL-LHC studies on ultraheavy diquarks, offering a robust method to probe beyond the Standard Model physics with multijet final states, especially when the decay branch to uχ is dominant.

title: Multifrequency evolution of the Integrated pulse profile of radio pulsars by implementing the inverse Compton mechanism
comment: 17 pages, 6 figures, 4 tables, accepted for publication in Journal of High Energy Astrophysics
summary: The Main Aim of this paper is to explain the emergence of new components of pulsars at higher radio bands by implementing the Inverse Compton Scattering Mechanism. From pulsar radio observation, it is seen that a couple of pulsars reveal new emission components at higher radio frequencies, although they show single-component emission at lower frequencies. We develop a brief outline, fostering inverse Compton scattering (ICS) of the low-frequency radio photons as a vulnerable source of scattering, susceptible to explaining the evolution of new components of some radio pulsars at higher bands. We couple the conventional curvature radiation (CR) mechanism and ICS, and suggest that the spectral convolution of the flux component individually from CR and the modulated template due to the ICS scattered component can be combined to reproduce such signatures associated with the diverse morphology of the integrated pulse profile. We reproduce the beam frequency diagram, the geometrical variation of different parameters of the emission geometry, as well as the multi-frequency evolution from theory. We have suitably tuned the input parameter space and given the combination of parameters that can tune to a particular scattered frequency in tabulated form. We conclude that ICS may be a responsible process for describing the emergence of new components in higher radio emission bands.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates the emergence of new pulsar emission components at higher radio frequencies using the Inverse Compton Scattering (ICS) mechanism.
AI.motivation: Observations show some pulsars exhibit multiple emission components at higher frequencies but only single components at lower frequencies. Previous models like curvature radiation alone cannot fully explain this behavior.
AI.method: Combines curvature radiation (CR) with ICS of low-frequency radio photons. Models spectral convolution of CR and ICS scattered components to reproduce observed pulse profiles. Analyzes beam frequency diagrams and parameter variations in emission geometry.
AI.result: Successful reproduction of multi-frequency emission evolution and parameter configurations that align with observed higher-frequency components. Tabulated input parameters demonstrating tunable sensitivity to specific frequencies.
AI.conclusion: ICS is identified as a viable mechanism explaining the emergence of new components in pulsar radio emissions at higher bands when integrated with CR.

title: BabaYaga@NLO at present and future $e^+e^-$ colliders. Celebrating 25 years of BabaYaga
comment: 11 pages, 2 tables. Presented at Matter To The Deepest Recent Developments In Physics Of Fundamental Interactions XLVI International Conference of Theoretical Physics, 14-19 September 2025, Katowice, Poland
summary: Precise QED radiative corrections for low- and high-energy electron-positron colliders are essential for accurate simulations of luminosity processes and precision tests of the Standard Model. We review the historical formulation and the recent developments of the BabaYaga@NLO event generator, which implements a QED Parton Shower matched with fixed-order calculations. We discuss the theoretical formulation of the code, as well as the assessment of its theoretical accuracy. Applications at low- and high-energy $e^+e^-$ colliders are presented, including latest result, together with the perspectives for future improvements, in view of the demanding precision requirements of future machines at the intensity frontier.

AI.tldr: The paper reviews the BabaYaga@NLO event generator, which combines QED Parton Shower with fixed-order calculations to provide precise radiative corrections for electron-positron colliders. It discusses the tool's theoretical foundations, validation, applications at various collider energies, and future outlook for meeting high-precision standards.
AI.motivation: To achieve accurate simulations and precision tests of the Standard Model at both low- and high-energy electron-positron colliders, precise QED radiative corrections are crucial. Existing methods may not sufficiently meet the stringent accuracy requirements of current and future collider experiments.
AI.method: The paper reviews the historical development and recent advancements of the BabaYaga@NLO event generator. It details the integration of QED Parton Shower with fixed-order calculations, theoretical formulation, and assessments of accuracy. Applications include analyses at different collider energies and展示 of the latest results.
AI.result: The generator demonstrates validated theoretical accuracy through rigorous assessments. Applications show its effectiveness in handling precision requirements across collider energies. Latest results highlight improved handling of radiative corrections compared to previous versions.
AI.conclusion: BabaYaga@NLO provides a reliable framework for precise QED radiative corrections, meeting current experimental demands. Future improvements are outlined to address upcoming challenges at the intensity frontier, ensuring continued relevance for next-generation collider experiments.

title: Investigating Pulsar Wind Nebula DA 495: Insights from LHAASO and Multi-Wavelength Observations
comment: Submitted to ApJ Letters, 10 pages, 4 figures, 1 table
summary: Pulsar wind nebula DA~495 (G65.7+1.2) has been extensively observed from radio to TeV $γ$-ray bands. We present LHAASO observations of DA~495, revealing an energy-dependent morphology, where an extended source with $r_{39}=0.19^{\circ}\pm0.02^{\circ}$ is detected by WCDA (0.4-15~TeV), and a point-like source with a 95\% upper limit of $r_{39}=0.11^{\circ}$ is observed by KM2A ($>25~\mathrm{TeV}$). The spectrum of the source extends beyond 100~TeV with a break or cutoff at a few tens of TeV. Our X-ray data analysis, based on Chandra and XMM-Newton observations, shows that the X-ray emission of DA~495 extends well to $\sim 6^{\prime}$, significantly larger than the size previously reported. The broadband spectral energy distribution across radio, X-ray and TeV $γ$-ray bands is phenomenologically described by a one-zone leptonic model, yielding an average magnetic field of $\sim$ 5 $\mathrm{μG}$, while Fermi-LAT spectral analysis indicates a likely presence of a $γ$-ray pulsar within the system. A time-dependent model, in which particle transport is convection-dominated in the inner region (within $\sim100^{\prime\prime}$) and diffusion-dominated in the outer region, successfully reproduces the observed radial profiles of X-ray surface brightness and spectral index, and also accounts for the TeV $γ$-ray emission detected by LHAASO, suggesting that DA~495 represents an evolved PWN with ongoing particle escape that gives rise to a TeV halo component -- that is, a PWN+halo system.

AI.tldr: The LHAASO observations reveal an energy-dependent morphology of the pulsar wind nebula DA 495, showing an extended TeV structure and a point-like component at higher energies. The analysis suggests DA 495 is an evolved PWN with ongoing particle escape, forming a PWN+halo system powered by a γ-ray pulsar.
AI.motivation: DA 495's multiwavelength observations are crucial for understanding the particle acceleration mechanisms and evolution in pulsar wind nebulae, especially the interplay between convection-dominated inner and diffusion-dominated outer regions.
AI.method: Combined LHAASO data (WCDA and KM2A), X-ray observations from Chandra/XMM-Newton, and Fermi-LAT analysis were used. A one-zone leptonic model and time-dependent particle transport model were applied to fit the SED and radial profiles.
AI.result: Detected extended TeV emission (r~0.19°) with a spectral break/cutoff. X-ray emission extends to ~6', larger than previous reports. A γ-ray pulsar is indicated. The particle transport model successfully explains the radial spectral features and TeV emission.
AI.conclusion: DA 495 is an evolved PWN with a TeV halo component due to particle escape. The system involves a central pulsar, convection/diffusion transport physics, and provides insights into high-energy emission mechanisms in PWNe.

title: Suppression of the jet quenching parameter near the critical temperature
summary: In this work, we study the jet quenching parameter ${\hat q}$ by using a background field effective theory. Particular attention is paid to its behavior near the critical temperature where nonperturbative effects induced by the deconfining phase transition are taken into account through a self-consistently introduced background field ${\cal Q}$. We adopt a theoretical approach in which the interaction rate between the energetic jet and medium partons is computed diagrammatically and the hard-thermal-loop resummed propagator is used to regulate the infrared divergence. In the presence of a background field, its influence on the jet quenching parameter manifests in two aspects. One is the modification on the screening mass in the resummed propagator, which leads to an enhanced ${\hat q}$. The other corresponds to the ${\cal Q}$-modified parton distribution function which is dominant and leads to a suppression of ${\hat q}$. Decreasing the temperature $T$, our result shows a non-monotonic $T$-dependence of the dimensionless ${\hat q}/T^3$. In the high temperature region, ${\hat q}/T^3$ shows an increase with decreasing $T$ due to the running coupling effect. Near the critical temperature, the background field plays a significant role and a dramatic suppression of ${\hat q}/T^3$ is found which qualitatively agrees with the Lattice simulation. In addition, the background field modification on the jet quenching parameter which is characterized by the ${\hat q}$-ratio can be simply parameterized by a polynomial expression depending only on the background field. This expression is expected to be useful for phenomenological applications in jet physics.

AI.tldr: The paper investigates the jet quenching parameter ${\hat q}$ using a background field effective theory, considering nonperturbative effects near the critical temperature. The study shows a non-monotonic temperature dependence of ${\hat q}/T^3$, with an enhancement at high temperatures and a suppression near criticality, aligning with lattice data. A polynomial parameterization of ${\hat q}$-ratio in terms of the background field is provided for phenomenological applications.
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of the jet quenching parameter ${\hat q}$ near the critical temperature, where deconfinement phase transitions induce nonperturbative effects, and to validate theoretical predictions against lattice simulations.
AI.method: A background field effective theory is employed. The interaction rate between energetic jets and medium partons is computed diagrammatically, using hard-thermal-loop resummed propagators to address infrared divergences. The background field ${\cal Q}$ modifies both the screening mass and parton distribution function, leading to competing effects on ${\hat q}$.
AI.result: The dimensionless ${\hat q}/T^3$ exhibits a non-monotonic temperature dependence: it increases with decreasing $T$ at high temperatures (due to running coupling effects) but suppresses dramatically near the critical temperature due to the background field, matching lattice results. A polynomial expression parameterizes ${\hat q}$-ratio based on the background field for practical applications.
AI.conclusion: The inclusion of background field effects captures both the enhancement and suppression of ${\hat q}$ near criticality, improving agreement with lattice data. The developed parameterization facilitates phenomenological studies in jet physics, particularly under nonperturbative conditions.

title: Broadband study of the Be/X-ray binary pulsar eRASSU J012422.9-724248 in the Magellanic Bridge, near the Eastern Wing of the Small Magellanic Cloud
comment: 10 pages, 13 figures, accepted for publication in MNRAS
summary: The first four all-sky surveys with eROSITA the soft X-ray instrument on board the Spektrum-Roentgen-Gamma (SRG) satellite revealed a new X-ray source, eRASSU J012422.9-724248, in the Magellanic Bridge, near the Eastern Wing of the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC). We performed a broadband timing and spectral analysis using the optical and X-ray data of eRASSU J012422.9-724248. Using the X-ray observations with eROSITA, Swift, NuSTAR and optical data from the optical Gravitational Lensing Experiment (OGLE) and the Las Cumbres Observatory (LCO), we confirm the nature of eRASSU J012422.9-724248 as a Be/X-ray binary (BeXRB) pulsar in the Magellanic bridge. The position is coincident with that of an early-type star (OGLE ID SMC732.10.7). We detect the spin period at 341.71 s in NuSTAR data and infer a period of 63.65 days from the 15 year monitoring with OGLE, that we interpret as the orbital period of the system. A tentative CRSF at ~12.3 keV is identified in NuSTAR spectra with ~1.8-sigma. The source appears to show a persistent X-ray luminosity and an optical magnitude transition on the long timescale. We propose eRASSU J012422.9-724248 is a new member of the class of persistent BeXRBs.

AI.tldr: The paper reports the discovery of eRASSU J012422.9-724248, a new Be/X-ray binary pulsar in the Magellanic Bridge, identified through multiwavelength observations. It has a 341.71-second spin period and a 63.65-day orbital period, with persistent X-ray emission and optical variability.
AI.motivation: To identify and characterize the nature of a newly detected X-ray source in the Magellanic Bridge using multi-satellite and ground-based observations.
AI.method: Broadband timing and spectral analysis combining eROSITA, Swift, NuSTAR X-ray data with OGLE and LCO optical data. Spin period detection via NuSTAR; orbital period derived from 15-year OGLE monitoring; spectral analysis for CRSF identification.
AI.result: Confirmed classification as a persistent Be/X-ray binary, with precise spin and orbital periods, a tentative CRSF at 12.3 keV, and evidence of long-term X-ray persistence and optical variability.
AI.conclusion: eRASSU J012422.9-724248 is established as a new member of persistent BeXRBs, contributing to understanding these systems' behavior in the Magellanic Bridge region.

title: Hadronic tau decays at higher orders in QCD
summary: We investigate higher-order perturbative corrections to hadronic $τ$ decays by applying nonlinear sequence-transformation techniques to the QCD correction $δ^{(0)}$. In particular, we employ the Shanks transformation and several of its generalisations constructed through Wynn's $\varepsilon$-algorithm, which are known to accelerate the convergence of slowly convergent or divergent series. These methods are used to extract higher-order information from the fixed-order perturbative expansion of $δ^{(0)}$. Within this framework, we estimate the perturbative coefficients $c_{5,1}$-$c_{12,1}$. In particular, we obtain $c_{5,1}=294^{+41}_{-21}$, $c_{6,1}=3415^{+450}_{-467}$, and $c_{7,1}=2.23^{+0.75}_{-0.49}\times 10^4$, where the quoted uncertainties reflect the spread among the different sequence transformations employed. Our analysis demonstrates that Shanks-type sequence transformations based on Wynn's $\varepsilon$-algorithm provide an efficient and systematic tool for probing higher-order perturbative effects in hadronic $τ$ decays in the absence of explicit multi-loop calculations.

AI.tldr: The paper explores using Shanks transformations and Wynn's ε-algorithm to estimate higher-order perturbative coefficients in hadronic τ decays, successfully predicting coefficients c_{5,1} to c_{12,1} without multi-loop calculations.
AI.motivation: To probe higher-order QCD corrections in τ decays when explicit multi-loop computations are missing, addressing the slow convergence or divergence of the perturbative series.
AI.method: Application of Shanks transformation and its generalizations via Wynn's ε-algorithm to the fixed-order perturbative expansion of δ^{(0)} to extract coefficients c_{5,1}-c_{12,1}.
AI.result: Estimated coefficients include c_{5,1}=294±error, c_{6,1}=3415±error, c_{7,1}=~22,300±error. Uncertainties stem from methodological variations.
AI.conclusion: Shanks-type sequence transformations offer a reliable, systematic approach for assessing higher-order effects in τ decays without relying on multi-loop calculations.

title: The Role of Plasma Lensing in Fast Radio Bursts
comment: 15 pages, 7 figures, accepted for publication in ApJ
summary: Growing evidence indicates that some fast radio bursts (FRBs) reside in dense, magneto-ionic environments where extrinsic propagation effects can substantially reshape the observed signal. Within a 1D Gaussian plasma-lens framework, we show that small, monotonic variations in the incidence angle of the FRB wavefront naturally generate both downward and upward sub-burst frequency drifts. We further demonstrate that distinct lensed paths that probe different rotation measures (RMs), can produce orthogonal polarization-angle (PA) jumps at gigahertz frequencies. In this picture, a $\sim 90^\circ$ PA transition requires only a modest RM contrast of order a few $\times10~\rm{rad~m^{-2}}$ between the multiple images. The chromatic activity of FRB 20180916B-earlier and narrower activity windows at higher frequencies-can be explained as preferential magnification near the outer caustic. Finally, the intrinsic resolution of a plasma lens provides an upper limit on the transverse emission size: lenses located close to the source yield magnetospheric-scale constraints and offer a practical means of discriminating between inner- and outer-magnetospheric emission scenarios. These results suggest that plasma lensing could account for multiple complex observational features of FRBs and may play a non-negligible role in modulating their observable properties.

AI.tldr: The study explores how plasma lensing in dense, magnetized environments can explain various observed features of fast radio bursts (FRBs), including frequency drifts, polarization changes, and chromatic activity patterns. It suggests plasma lensing significantly influences FRB properties and helps differentiate emission scenarios.
AI.motivation: To understand the complex observational features of FRBs caused by extrinsic propagation effects in dense magneto-ionic environments, such as frequency drifts, polarization jumps, and chromatic activity. The goal is to evaluate plasma lensing's role in modulating these signals.
AI.method: A 1D Gaussian plasma-lens framework was used to model FRB signal propagation. Simulations analyzed how varying incidence angles and rotation measure (RM) contrasts between lensed paths produce observable effects like frequency drifts and polarization-angle (PA) jumps. The model also examined chromatic activity patterns using FRB 20180916B as a case study.
AI.result: The model shows that plasma lensing can generate both upward/downward frequency drifts and 90° PA jumps with modest RM contrasts (~few×10 rad/m²). Chromatic activity (e.g., narrower high-frequency active windows) is explained by magnification near caustics. Lenses provide an upper limit on emission size, distinguishing magnetospheric emission regions.
AI.conclusion: Plasma lensing is a plausible mechanism explaining multiple FRB observational features, indicating its non-negligible role in shaping FRB properties. This framework aids in constraining emission scenarios and understanding propagation effects in astrophysical environments.

title: Measurements of H$\toττ$ cross-section at FCC-ee
summary: The Future Circular Collider (FCC) stands at the forefront of the European Strategy for Particle Physics as the future flagship project at CERN. The H$\toττ$ decay, featuring a large branching ratio, clean identification in the FCC-ee environment, and the possibility to reconstruct polarization information, is an excellent channel to measure Higgs properties. This work shows the expected precision for the H$\toττ$ cross-section measurement at the FCC-ee in the ZH production mechanism at $\sqrt{s}=$240 GeV and $\sqrt{s}=$365 GeV, as well as via the vector boson fusion process at $\sqrt{s}=$365 GeV. Furthermore, we explore and evaluate a set of methods for reconstructing tau decays. These techniques are critical for unlocking the full physics potential of the FCC-ee and for improving the understanding of tau-related observables in both Standard Model measurements and New Physics searches. The results obtained significantly enhance the FCC-ee outlook in the H$\toττ$ channel, improving it by at least an order of magnitude compared to the current sensitivity of measurements' performance at the LHC.

AI.tldr: The paper presents an analysis of Higgs boson properties using the H→ττ decay channel at the FCC-ee collider, achieving precision cross-section measurements and advanced tau decay reconstruction methods that surpass LHC capabilities by an order of magnitude.
AI.motivation: To leverage the FCC-ee's capabilities for precise Higgs property measurements, exploit the favorable characteristics of H→ττ decays (high branching ratio, clean identification, and polarization information), and improve tau-related observables for both Standard Model studies and New Physics searches.
AI.method: Simulations of ZH production at √s=240 GeV and 365 GeV, and vector boson fusion processes at √s=365 GeV at FCC-ee. Techniques for tau decay reconstruction were explored and evaluated to maximize physics potential.
AI.result: Significant improvements in measurement precision over the LHC, with results enhancing the FCC-ee's capabilities in the H→ττ channel by at least an order of magnitude in sensitivity.
AI.conclusion: The proposed methods and precision measurements validate the FCC-ee as a transformative tool for Higgs physics, enabling deeper insights into Standard Model parameters and potential discoveries in beyond-Standard-Model physics through tau decay analyses.

title: Little Red Dots as Hidden Neutrino Sources
summary: Little Red Dots (LRDs) are enigmatic, compact, red galaxies at high redshift, $z\sim 4$-$7$, discovered by the James Webb Space Telescope. Broad emission lines in the absence of X-ray and radio counterparts suggest that they host accreting supermassive black holes embedded in dense gaseous envelopes. This black-hole-envelope configuration facilitates efficient photohadronic interactions and neutrino production. Remarkably, their observed source number density and luminosity are compatible with the energetics of the diffuse neutrino background. We consider that relativistic jets and outflows are launched from the black hole and propagate through low-density polar funnels within envelopes, where particle acceleration and neutrino emission occur. This leads to LRDs being effectively hidden sources. Our analytic and numerical calculations show that, in an optimistic scenario, LRDs can contribute $\sim 30\%$ of the observed diffuse background at TeV$-$sub-PeV energies, predominantly through photomeson production. At high neutrino energies, $\gtrsim 10^{5.5}~{\rm GeV}$, inverse-Compton cooling of muons modifies the resulting flavor ratio, providing a distinctive diagnostic for IceCube-Gen2 and other upcoming neutrino telescopes.

AI.tldr: Little Red Dots (LRDs) are high-redshift galaxies hosting supermassive black holes with dense gas envelopes, which produce neutrinos via photohadronic interactions. They could contribute up to 30% of the diffuse TeV-sub-PeV neutrino background, with unique flavor ratios at >10^5.5 GeV helping identify their origin with next-gen telescopes.
AI.motivation: The discovery of LRDs by JWST requires understanding their role as potential sources of the diffuse neutrino background. Their observed properties (red color, broad emission lines without X-ray/radio activity) suggest hidden black holes facilitating neutrino production.
AI.method: Analytic and numerical simulations modeled jet/outflow dynamics through low-density gas funnels around accreting black holes. Calculated neutrino production efficiencies and energy spectra considering photomeson interactions and muon inverse-Compton cooling effects.
AI.result: LRDs can account for ~30% of the observed diffuse neutrino background at TeV-sub-PeV energies. High-energy (>1e5.5 GeV) neutrinos show altered flavor ratios, offering a detectable signature for future neutrino telescopes.
AI.conclusion: LRDs represent new astrophysical neutrino sources, bridging high-redshift galaxy evolution and particle physics. Their unique neutrino signatures require observation with IceCube-Gen2 to confirm their contribution to the cosmic neutrino budget.

title: Energy levels of multiscale bound states from QED energy-momentum trace
summary: Energy levels of QED bound states, which depend on a number of independent mass parameters, can be calculated as matrix elements of the QED energy-momentum trace. As an example of such system we consider muonic hydrogen. The leading one-loop corrections to its energy levels depend on the electron and muon masses. These corrections are calculated as matrix elements of the energy-momentum trace. Respective one-loop trace diagrams are different from the standard Lamb shift diagrams. We explain analytically and diagrammatically why two different sets of diagrams lead to the same results. Similar relationships should also hold beyond the one-loop approximation.

AI.tldr: The paper calculates one-loop QED corrections to muonic hydrogen energy levels using energy-momentum trace matrix elements, showing equivalence between trace diagrams and standard Lamb shift diagrams analytically and diagrammatically, with implications for higher-loop approximations.
AI.motivation: To understand how mass-dependent QED corrections affect bound state energy levels, using muonic hydrogen as a case study, and to clarify the relationship between different diagrammatic approaches in QED calculations.
AI.method: Calculates one-loop corrections via matrix elements of the QED energy-momentum trace for muonic hydrogen, compares trace diagrams with standard Lamb shift diagrams analytically and through diagrammatic analysis.
AI.result: Shows analytically and diagrammatically that two distinct diagram sets (trace-based vs. standard Lamb shift) produce identical one-loop results, suggesting similar relationships may exist at higher loop orders.
AI.conclusion: The equivalence of different diagrammatic approaches in QED calculations is rigorously demonstrated at one-loop level, implying potential generalizations to multi-loop corrections for precision spectroscopy studies.

title: Suppression of Fast Flavor Conversion by Red Turbulence in Supernovae
summary: Fast flavor conversions (FFCs) in supernovae, driven by neutrino-neutrino refraction, can catastrophically equilibrate flavors and potentially affect the neutrino-driven explosion. We present a pivotal insight: matter density fluctuations characterized by red spectra ($ν<0$), naturally arising in stratified supernova environments, can suppress such instabilities by inducing accelerated decoherence. By deriving exact analytical solutions for two-flavor evolution in red turbulent matter-where correlations grow as $t^{|ν|}$-we uncover a novel acceleration of coherence loss. This dynamical decoherence mechanism raises an effective energy barrier against the collective growth of flavor instabilities. Translating our master-equation results into an effective damping rate for FFC linear analysis, we find that realistic red turbulence ($ν\sim -1$, fluctuation strength $ξ_ν\sim 0.1$) can elevate the FFC threshold by a factor of $\sim 3-5$, potentially stabilizing regions that would otherwise undergo explosion-killing flavor equilibration (or vice versa). Our work provides the first analytical criterion for FFC suppression in turbulent media and identifies red turbulence as a critical, physics-grounded ingredient missing from current supernova models.

AI.tldr: The paper demonstrates that red spectrum matter density fluctuations in supernova environments can suppress fast flavor conversions (FFCs) by accelerating decoherence, thereby potentially stabilizing the neutrino-driven explosion mechanism.
AI.motivation: To address the potential catastrophic effects of FFCs on supernova explosions by exploring how natural matter density fluctuations influence these instabilities.
AI.method: The authors derived exact analytical solutions for two-flavor neutrino evolution in red turbulent matter, analyzed the growth of correlations, and translated findings into an effective damping rate for FFC linear analysis.
AI.result: Red turbulence with parameters ν ~ -1 and fluctuation strength ξν ~ 0.1 can increase the FFC threshold by 3-5 times, suggesting stabilization of regions prone to flavor equilibration.
AI.conclusion: Red turbulence is a critical factor missing from current supernova models, offering an analytical criterion for suppressing FFCs and highlighting the need for its inclusion in future models.

title: Globally Optimal Contour Deformations with Neural Networks
summary: In this article, we explore the use of contour deformation for the numerical evaluation of Feynman integrals after sector decomposition. In existing codes, the contour of integration is determined heuristically for each phase-space point by sampling the integrand. In this work, we introduce a method for choosing the contour deformation for an entire phase-space region using only an initial sampling or training step. We demonstrate that the resulting integrand has a lower variance than that obtained with heuristic methods and show that optimising a contour to reduce the estimated error of a Quasi-Monte Carlo sample is an ill-defined problem. The a priori knowledge of the integration path obtained in this work can be used to improve the speed of conventional integration methods or be leveraged for integration using neural networks, where, crucially, it removes the need to retrain the neural network for each phase-space point. The techniques described in this work can be adapted to other problems where a non-trivial integration path has to be chosen subject to a set of constraints.

AI.tldr: The article presents a new method for selecting contour deformations in Feynman integral evaluations post-sector decomposition, using an initial training step for phase-space regions. This approach reduces integrand variance, avoids per-phase-space-point retraining in neural network methods, and offers broader applicability.
AI.motivation: Address the limitations of heuristic contour selection in existing codes by providing a systematic method that reduces variance and computational demands, especially beneficial for enhancing conventional integration and neural network-based approaches.
AI.method: Introduce a contour deformation selection method based on an initial sampling/training phase for entire phase-space regions, demonstrating its superiority over heuristic methods in variance reduction. Also show that optimizing contours to minimize QMC error is ill-posed.
AI.result: The proposed method yields integrands with lower variance than heuristic approaches. It also establishes that error-based contour optimization for QMC is problematic, while showcasing the method's versatility for integration path pre-specification in constrained scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The technique improves integration efficiency, benefits neural network applications by eliminating per-phase retraining, and is adaptable to other problems requiring constrained contour selection, opening avenues for optimization in computational physics.

title: Analytical approaches to the study of the phase of the visibility function
summary: In radio interferometric observations, the main source of information is the complex visibility function, which includes amplitude and phase. In this paper, the dependence of the phase of the visibility function on the base projection is investigated when used in radio interferometry with space bases up to six Earth diameters. It is shown that for small values of the base projections, this dependence has a universal character and is consistent with the results of numerical magnetohydrodynamic models.

summary: The intrabinary shocks (IBS) in spider pulsars emit non-thermal synchrotron X-rays from accelerated electrons and positrons in the shocked pulsar wind, likely energized by magnetic reconnection. The double-peaked X-ray light curves from these shocks have been well characterized in several spider systems. In this paper, we analyze Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer (IXPE) observations of the redback pulsar J1723$-$2837 to examine the expected synchrotron polarization. Using advanced extraction methods that include spatial, temporal, and particle background weights, we constrain the polarization of the IBS. We compare different models for the magnetic field in the radiation zone and find that the best fit prefers a striped pulsar wind model over other polarized models, with maximum polarization degree of the IBS emission component $Π_{\rm IBS}=36^{+16}_{-15}\%$, in addition to an unpolarized non-IBS component. Since this is only 2.4$σ$, we cannot claim strong preference over an unpolarized model; we report a $99\%$ confidence level upper limit on the total polarization of both IBS and non-IBS components $Π_{99}<36\%$, which is improved over the $50\%$ limit obtained in previous work. The best-fit polarization of the IBS component is consistent with numerical simulations. Detailed tests of such models are accessible to future measurements.
